awd_titl_txt: Belmont Forum Collaborative Research Food-Water-Energy Nexus: Globally and Locally-sustainable Food-Water-Energy Innovation in Urban Living Labs
awd_abstract_narration:
Many cities across the globe are facing difficult challenges managing their food, water and energy systems. The challenges stem from the fact that the issues of food, water and energy are often tightly connected with each other, not only locally but also globally. This is known as the Food-Water-Energy (FWE) nexus.  An effective solution to a local water problem may cause new local problems with food or energy, or cause new water problems at the global level. On a local scale, it is difficult to anticipate whether solutions to one issue in the nexus are sustainable across food, water and energy systems, both at the local and the global scale.  Innovative solutions that encompass the nexus are particularly important to enable cities to better manage their food, water and energy systems and understand the benefits and tradeoffs for different solutions.  

This award supports U.S. researchers participating in a project competitively selected by a 29-country initiative through the joint Belmont Forum- Joint Programming Initiative (JPI) Urban Europe.  The Sustainable Urbanization Global Initiative (SUGI)/Food-Water-Energy Nexus is a multilateral initiative designed to support research projects that bring together the fragmented research and expertise across the globe to find innovative solutions to the Food-Water-Energy Nexus challenge.  The call seeks to develop more resilient, applied urban solutions to benefit a much wider range of stakeholders. The rapid urbanization of the world's population underscores the importance of this focus. International partners were invited to develop solutions for this challenge.  The funds requested will be used to support U.S. participants to cooperate in consortia that consist of partners from at least three of the participating countries and that bring together natural scientists, social scientists and research users (e.g., civil society, NGOs, and industry).  Participants from other countries are funded through their national funding organizations. 

This project seeks to develop a novel approach to produce innovative solutions to FWE challenges that are both locally and globally sustainable, through experiments in Urban Living Labs in Austria, Brazil, Germany Netherlands, South Africa, Sweden and the USA.  Urban Living Labs are a forum for innovation, applied to the development of new products, systems, services and processes, employing working methods to integrate people into the entire development process as users and co-creator, to explore, examine, experiment, test and evaluate new ideas, scenarios, processes, systems, concepts and creative solutions in complex and real contexts. The project will involve a range of urban stakeholders early in the creative and evaluative processes of innovation, and the solutions produced will be tested for environmental soundness and economic viability and social acceptability and robustness.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This international research project has had both intellectual and broader outcomes that contribute to the advancement of sustainable food-water-energy innovations. Research was conducted in seven Urban Living Labs (ULLs) in The U.S., South America, Africa, and Europe. ULLs are collaborations between researchers and representatives from government, business, and civic organizations who work together towards sustainability goals in a given urban area. The Phoenix area ULL focused on research in support of the sustainable local food economy and was an institutional partnership between Arizona State University, the non-profit organization Local First Arizona supporting local businesses, and the city administrations of Phoenix and Tempe. Rather than focusing on direct changes in the sustainable food economy, such as business startups, jobs created, money kept in the local economy, food miles, etc., the ULL's research centered on 'upstream drivers'. Upstream drivers are one or two degrees removed and support such direct changes, in particular when structured as a functional entrepreneurial/economic 'ecosystem'. They include capacities (knowledge and skills), resources, regulations, political support, public opinion, etc., and are facilitated by business development providers, elected city officials, city administration staff, consultants, educators, and other stakeholders.

Outcomes (intellectual and broader) were produced at three levels: (1) the international research project; (2) the local ULL partnership; and (3) projects conducted by the local ULL; and also include (4) educational outcomes.

1. General knowledge and resources supporting ULLs and sustainable food-water-energy innovations worldwide have been created as a result of the international research collaboration. Data and findings from the international ULLs have been used to improve understanding of how ULLs function and how the sustainability of food-water-energy experiments within them can be improved. This knowledge has been translated into general guidelines and tools for ULL practitioners. The ASU team has specifically contributed to the development of knowledge related to the operation of Urban Living Labs at the Food-Water-Energy nexus, conducting a cross-case comparison to identify success factors for ULLs and guidelines their development. In addition, the team has conducted an analysis of transformative capacity building in ULLs to determine how change related to sustainability can be created, or not, through the development and implementation of real-world experiments in ULL settings.

2. Specific capacity (knowledge, skills) and resources have been created among Phoenix area ULL partners to strategically collaborate on projects towards the goal of developing a sustainable local food economy. The partners have learned how to work together in such a coalition, how to select and develop strategic pilot projects ('experiments') with local stakeholders, and to transfer and scale the results of these pilot projects for broader impact. The capacities built within the partnering organizations will be carried forward into spinoff and new projects beyond the GLOCULL project.

3. The ULL conducted four main pilot projects (experiments) that made advancements in diverse sectors of the sustainable local food economy: i) created a multi-stakeholder coalition for preserving sustainable urban farmland and working with one urban farm to develop a community land trust; ii) reduced barriers for small food business by providing guides to navigate food regulations and city codes; iii) raised the profile of indigenous food entrepreneurs by sharing in-depth stories of their success; and iv) worked with craft breweries on the adoption of sustainable business practices and models (in cooperation with the Arizona Craft Brewers Guild). Ancillary projects included developing a sustainable international coffee supply chain between Arizona and Mexico, developing a startup plan for a sustainable plant-to-bottle kombucha worker cooperative, and developing a startup plan for a cooperative food forest business.  Outcomes included: raising public awareness of problems and solutions for the sustainable local food economy; raising awareness of problems and solutions with city staff and elected officials; building capacity of small businesses and entrepreneurs for adopting sustainable business practices or starting sustainable businesses; building capacity of other stakeholders to support businesses adopt sustainable business practices; forming new networks among stakeholders; forming new organizations to support the further development of the sustainable local food economy; creating tools and resources to support sustainable food business startups; and changing city codes to reduce barriers to forming small food businesses.

4. The project engaged graduate students from Arizona State University in preparing and delivering stakeholder events and conducting supporting research on problems and solutions for the sustainable local food economy. Engagement took place through project-based learning as part of regular courses, student research assistant positions, and master's and doctoral theses work. Outcomes included the development of knowledge and skills of students to develop and run ULLs, the consulting services to small businesses on adopting sustainable business practices, and the creation of new sustainable business practice knowledge.
